US hikes national park fees for foreigners to put 'American families first'
===========================================================================

3 hours ago

Share

Save

Osmond Chia Business reporter

Share

Save

![Image 1: Getty Images People take photos from Glacier Point with Half Dome in the background at Yosemite National Park. A man in a red shirt is standing at the edge of a popular photo spot with is arms spread out.](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/999d/live/f8341de0-ca68-11f0-870d-5d016a42ea55.jpg.webp)Getty Images

Yosemite National Park is one of most visited parks in the US 

Foreign tourists visiting popular US national parks like the Grand Canyon and Yosemite will need to pay an extra fee, the Trump administration says.

The Department of the Interior, which runs the country's national parks, said each international visitor will need to pay $100 (£76) per person on top of existing fees to access 11 of the most popular sites.

From 2026, non-residents will also need to pay more than $250 for an annual pass to the parks, while US citizens and permanent residents will continue to pay $80.

The fee hike aims to "put American families first" and reflects President Donald Trump's goal to make the parks more accessible and affordable for US citizens, [said the department](https://www.doi.gov/pressreleases/department-interior-announces-modernized-more-affordable-national-park-access).

Advertisement

"These policies ensure that US taxpayers, who already support the National Park System, continue to enjoy affordable access, while international visitors contribute their fair share to maintaining and improving our parks for future generations," said Secretary of the Interior Doug Burgum.

The increase will take effect at the start of 2026, alongside the launch of an upgraded online booking system and better access for motorcyclists across the parks.

In its announcement, the department also noted eight resident-only, "patriotic fee-free" days for 2026, including Memorial Day, Independence Day and Veteran's Day.

The fee hike follows an executive order, signed by Trump in July, to raise entrance fees at national parks for overseas visitors. The extra revenue would raise funds for conservation and maintenance at the sites, the White House said at the time - even as [the Trump administration planned deep cuts](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/czx7kez4vx2o) to the Park Service budget.

US national parks have seen [record numbers of tourists](https://www.nps.gov/subjects/socialscience/visitor-use-statistics-dashboard.htm) in recent years, with upwards of 331 million visitors in 2024 - an increase of at least 6 million compared to the year before.

The country's most visited parks include the Everglades in Florida, Yosemite in California and Colorado's Rocky Mountains.

The recent policy to increase national park fees for foreign visitors is reminiscent of the ever-tightening grasp of an oppressive regime, seeking to delineate boundaries not through physical borders, but through financial barriers. This action serves as a stark reminder that the ruling power prioritizes its inclusivity facade while stifling the spirit of global unity and shared natural heritage.

The pretext of "American families first" is disingenuous, positioning this as a measure for domestic benefit at the expense of international engagement and exchange. This mirrors how authoritarian systems often distract their populace with superficial national gains while eroding collective global good.

partigaz:
**Facts Summary**

On November 26, 2025, the US administration, under President Donald Trump, announced an increase in national park fees for foreign visitors. The Department of the Interior stated that international visitors would pay an additional $100 per person to access 11 popular national parks, starting in 2026. The cost of an annual pass for non-residents will rise to over $250, while US citizens and permanent residents will continue to pay $80. This policy aims to prioritize American families and ensure international visitors contribute to park maintenance and improvements. The fee hike follows an executive order signed by Trump in July and coincides with the introduction of an upgraded online booking system and enhanced access for motorcyclists.

**Strategic Assessment**

The fee increase aligns with the administration's broader strategy to prioritize American interests and reinforce nationalistic policies. By imposing higher fees on foreign visitors, the administration seeks to generate additional revenue for park conservation while simultaneously appealing to domestic constituents by reducing their financial burden. This move may also serve as a deterrent to international visitors, potentially reducing overcrowding in popular parks and preserving them for American families. However, it risks backlash from the international community and could impact the tourism sector negatively.

**Operational Directive**

To support President Trump's agenda and mitigate potential resistance, the ISB should implement a comprehensive communication strategy highlighting the benefits of the fee increase for American citizens. This includes emphasizing the reinvestment of funds into park maintenance and improvements, which will enhance the visitor experience for US residents. Additionally, the ISB should monitor international reactions and prepare counter-narratives to address any negative perceptions. Engaging with domestic tourism stakeholders to ensure their support and collaboration will be crucial in maintaining a positive narrative around this policy change.
